message: Maybe this is just me who thinks it'd be fun, but back on IRC in the old days, we had a little bit running to keep track of ++ and -- statements in the chat
And then the bot would increment "Stargate" +1 in its own database

Sometimes you'd find funny stuff in there that people did which you might've missed, like “Getting a nice triple-scoop chocolate mint, lemon merengue and peach ice cream and then having your elbow bumped by some guy not paying attention and your ice cream falling to the floor”--
But usually, it'd be things like “Gah, AT&T--! They charged me for roaming even though I never left the country, I was just _near_ the Canadian border!”
Definitely a nerdy thing, and definitely more programmer-humor than mainstream, but it lived perfectly fine along crowds that never used it or even "got" it
I think it would be fun to have here, but I could well be the only one
In any case, I made it a hack for vBulletin way back when, and it was super popular
This could easily be done as a simple bot.
We tracked it as Karma, and used it as a means to express ourselves mostly comically
It was rarely “abused” really, most of the time it was just a subtle thing that some people participated in, and never stood out much on its own
So for example, we could be talking about how Stargate++ was awesome last night
And of course, there was a site where you could read the whole Karma list
And then AT&T would go down 1.
ie: in user-space, rather than baked in.
yes I think @justinlilly has a good suggestion ... this is probably better as a bot
since then you can control the behavior
There wouldn't be a bot for it  if it was baked on :P
in*
Wouldn't work though; a bot could never access the entirety of the site.
nor is it likely that people actually want a karma bot always.
And with invites in place for groups, getting a karma bot when you want one seems quite easy.
okay, I don't know why you'd want a site-wide feature like this anyways... I would think you would want it scoped to your own group?
otherwise there would probably be a battle between Django Community and Rails
If you don't want to participate in Karma upvotes/downvotes, just don't participate, no?
(mainly, I don't see the problem)
"oh, foo++ does something. What else does this do?" thereby making the concept a teensy bit harder to grok.
just another thing for people to learn when they get to the service.
@leah If I had a karma bot, I would totally increment you for that comment. ;)
/me @leah++'s into the ether.
Mm, that's fair - back on IRC and on my community, we all knew each other well enough to not get into a pissing contest over whatever X we liked was better
But that wouldn't apply here necessarily at all
